0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: number of Factor IX international units required = body weight (kg) times desired Factor IX increase (%) times 1 international unit/kg
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Alphanine(R) SD: mild hemorrhage (20% to 30% of normal Factor IX level), 20 to 30 international units/kg IV twice daily until hemorrhage stops and healing is achieved (1 to 2 days)
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Alphanine(R) SD: moderate hemorrhage (25% to 50% of normal Factor IX level), 25 to 50 international units/kg IV twice a day until healing is achieved (2-7 days)
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Alphanine(R) SD: major hemorrhage (50% of normal Factor IX level), 30 to 50 international units/kilogram IV twice a day for at least 3 to 5 days. Followed by 20 international units/kg IV (20% of normal Factor IX level) twice a day. Treatment may need to be continued for up to 10 days
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Alphanine(R) SD: surgery (50% to 100% of normal Factor IX level), 50 to 100 international units/kg IV twice daily for 7 to 10 days
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Mononine(R): mild hemorrhage (15% to 25% of normal Factor IX level), 20 to 30 international units/kg IV once and repeated in 24 hours if needed
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Mononine(R): major trauma or surgery (25% to 50% of normal Factor IX level), up to 75 international units/kg IV every 18 to 30 hours up to 10 days if needed

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: number of Factor IX international units required = body weight (kg) times desired Factor IX increase (%) times 1 international unit/kg
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Mononine(R): mild hemorrhage (15% to 25% of normal Factor IX level), 20 to 30 international units/kg IV once and repeated in 24 hours if needed
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Mononine(R): major trauma or surgery (25% to 50% of normal Factor IX level), up to 75 international units/kg IV every 18 to 30 hours up to 10 days if needed

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); risk of thromboembolic complications
  • factor IX inhibitors, development of; increased risk for hypersensitivity reaction, including anaphylaxis
  • fibrinolysis; risk of thromboembolic complications
  • high doses; greater risk of myocardial infarction, disseminated intravascular coagulation, venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
  • human plasma contained in medication; potential risk for transmission of infection, including theoretical risk for transmission of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis; reported for all factor IX products
  • immune tolerance induction, attempted in patients with factor IX inhibitors and a history of allergic reactions; potential risk for nephrotic syndrome
  • liver disease; increased risk of thromboembolic complications
  • major deletion mutations of factor IX gene; increased risk of inhibitor formation and acute hypersensitivity reaction
  • neonates; increased risk of thromboembolic complications
  • post-operative patients; increased risk of thromboembolic complications
  • thromboembolic phenomena; increased risk of thromboembolic complications

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Factor IX: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Factor IX: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Flushing, Injection site pain, Injection site reaction
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea, Taste sense altered
  • Neurologic:Dizziness, Headache
Serious
  • Hematologic:Thromboembolic disorder
  • Immunologic:Allergic reaction to drug, Anaphylaxis
  • Renal:Nephrotic syndrome
  • Respiratory:Dyspnea
  • Other:Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Overall, all forms of factor IX achieve hemostasis through the same mechanism. A complex of factor VII and tissue factor (via the extrinsic coagulation pathway) and factor XIa (via the intrinsic pathway) activate factor IX which, in combination with factor VIII:C, activates factor X to Xa. Through this pathway, prothrombin is converted to thrombin which, in turn, converts fibrinogen to fibrin.

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• Mononine(R): 23 to 31 hours
  • Alphanine(R) SD: 21 hours
  • Solvent detergent treated products: 19 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • warm to room temperature
  • use double-ended needle to transfer diluent (provided) to single-dose vial; direct flow of diluent against side of vial
  • let vial stand until contents are in solution and then swirl gently; do NOT shake; do NOT invert vial until ready to withdraw contents
  • use as soon as possible (within 3 h) after reconstitution; discard unused portion
  • using microaggregate filter (provided), withdraw dose into syringe; discard filter
  • administer Mononine(R) by slow infusion at a rate approximately 2 mL/min; administer Alphanine(R) SD at a rate not to exceed 10 mL/min

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• normalization of coagulation parameters
  • factor IX assays at least once daily prior to infusion; in patients with severe hemorrhage or undergoing major surgery
  • early signs and symptoms of hypersensitivity reactions; especially in patients with major deletion mutations in the factor IX gene, rate of administration may need to be adjusted and/or therapy discontinued
  • signs and symptoms of infection; human plasma derived product and theoretical risk of infection including viruses and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease agent
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis, disseminated intravascular coagulation; especially in patients with known liver disease, surgical patients, neonates, and patients with risk factors predisposing to thrombosis

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Alphanine SD
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 IU
  • Mononine
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 IU
